name: Mr. Alcot
symptoms: Progressive shortness of breath over 6 months
history: Former smoker (40 pack-years), worked in construction for 35 years. History of hypertension controlled with medication. Father died of lung cancer.
physical_exam: Appears older than stated age, mild respiratory distress. Decreased breath sounds bilaterally with fine crackles at bases. Finger clubbing noted. No cyanosis, no peripheral edema.
labs: CBC: mild anemia. Basic metabolic panel within normal limits. Elevated inflammatory markers.

visualFindings.caption: Finger clubbing - indicative of chronic hypoxemia, commonly seen in certain pulmonary conditions

auscultation.title: Lung Sounds - Bilateral Rales
auscultation.description: Auscultation reveals bilateral rales (crackles), suggestive of interstitial fluid accumulation

models3D.title: Lung Pathology Model

differential_diagnoses.supporting_evidence: Progressive dyspnea, dry cough, bibasilar crackles, finger clubbing, history of construction work
differential_diagnoses.recommended_tests: High-resolution CT, pulmonary function tests, possibly lung biopsy

differential_diagnoses.supporting_evidence: Smoking history, progressive dyspnea, dry cough
Progressive dyspnea, dry cough, bibasilar crackles, occupational exposure
differential_diagnoses.recommended_tests: High-resolution CT, pulmonary function tests, bronchoscopy

treatment_plan: Referral to pulmonologist, antifibrotic therapy (pirfenidone or nintedanib), supplemental oxygen as needed, pulmonary rehabilitation.
follow_up: Regular monitoring of lung function, oxygen levels, and disease progression. Consideration for lung transplant evaluation if rapid progression.
